ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: if you get a project that's what you were hoping for, it can be very very instructive / useful.

Field trip: visit to NRDC's offices for an energy efficient panel. Also private tour of Empire State Building retrofit, which was great.Regarding the class, it all depends on your client and the work you do for them.That being said, the class may be a little too "legal" for some F&ES students (if you are in it for the client work and not for the law side of things).

The whole course is an out-of-class project. There were a few in-class exercises but they were not well-introduced or explained and expectations were unclear, which made it difficult to get anything out of them. The nature of this course is weirdly amorphic. Some groups are doing legal work, others LCAs, others business plans. It's all over the map. If it's a legal clinic, it should be run as a legal clinic, with appropriate projects, appropriate oversight (i.e., a team of professors, not a single part-time adjunct), and appropriate in-class exercises and discussions.
The field trip to NRDC was a wonderful learning experience. I'm so glad I went. The sessions were extremely interesting. I also enjoyed the mock hearing.
This has been one of the most valuable courses I have taken at FES. I have learned a lot of professional skills through this course.

Clinics are probably the most useful classes at FES because the student consulting work gives us real-life experience with the work and situations we will face in our careers. By far one of the most valuable experiences at FES.
I only worked for the client, and evaluated this course last semester.

This course provides experience in analyzing and helping to solve real world problems. In that, it is unique and it provides students with the opportunity to effectively "intern" on a part time basis with the client organization. The workload is intense, which was stressed by both the faculty and the TA, but one never gets a true sense for how much so until one lives it. To do the course project right requires lots of time, which sometimes made me feel like the lecture courses piled on me. However, those lecture courses were very useful, and I would not suggest eliminating them.
N/A
It is a clinic course for which I did not take the classroom portion so some questions do not apply.
Gaining client exposure.The diversity of choices for the client work.
The opportunity to work with a client and gain familiarity with legal research tools.
The opportunity to interact with a diverse group of clients was the best part of this course.
The opportunity to work with clients.

Working on a solutions-focussed project that will (hopefully) actually be utilized by practitioners. There is far too much theory taught in this school, and students don't get enough practice putting that theory to work on real projects. This should be a primary focus of a professional degree program.

Obviously, the ability to work on an applied project and actually help a client in the real world is fairly unusual. I feel like I really learned how to prepare a report for an NGO, and I also feel good that something I wrote will be of value to other people, rather than disappearing into a professor's desk drawer.
The opportunity to work on a project in a region of interest to me.
The student consulting work and working directly with a client.
Opportunity to work on real problems and to get to know client organization. Opportunity to go VERY deep into an issue.

Working with a real client and having the ability to have a neutral professor to assist in the interaction with the clinic projects. Kit really helped each of us ask the right questions of our project supervisors and we learned a lot from the experience.
The opportunity to work closely with a client organization.
The coaching.
Being able to produce work that our client organization may use in policy making.
It was nice to work on real projects.
Client interaction
Access to an experiential and real-life project.Ability to work with actors involved in current environmental issues.Opportunity to see in action ongoing climate change negotiations

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: bimonthly team meetings with the prof weren't necessarily useful, though I do understand they were there in case a team was falling behind etc.
Eliminate the timesheet/time tracking system. We are not in the workplace, and it's a pain to constantly keep track of hours.
Most class sessions and were not particularly valuable. The class on writing as very basic and covered material that all students already know, so may not be necessary.

The strict 120 hour requirement may not be the best way to gauge students' performance for the class/client. I know that many project deliverables were complete in well under the 120 hour requirement. Asking that students adhere strictly to this requirement encouraged fabrication of the hours, giving the instructors/TA an inaccurate measure of how much time was actually needed to complete a given requirement for a given project.
I don't really have many improvements. I think it runs pretty well. The 12 hours a week is pretty rough; but people do it, obviously.
Nothing; this was a great course.

Nothing that Yale/the instructor can actually improve, unless it's screening and prepping the clients a bit better about what the students can deliver and how much interaction/direction the students do or do not need.

In my case, the client organization was not so clear as to what issue we could solve or work on initially (up front). As such, the scope of our project shifted a few times, which was a bit disorienting and likely cost us time. Also, the client was not very responsive at times, taking long times to respond to the few emails sent to them. Perhaps clients could be coached a bit more on what is expected of them for purposes of the clinic.Lastly, the day of the class presentations (last day) did not run as timely as scheduled. Some groups were allowed to take much longer than their allotted time, which resulted in a time crunch for other groups. I would suggest being much stricter about the allotted time for each group. Students should understand that as professionals they will need to stick to the schedules they are given and not deviate needlessly.
There might be a need for mid-semester group evaluations. I think this would have had some group members push forward towards the end of the semester rather than lagging behind.

The timing of the mock trial and climate change negotiations was inconvenient since they were both in the same week. It would help in the future if they were spread out more so we can better balance our time with client work.Furthermore, our client at NREL could have been managed a little better in terms of expectations. The instructions he provided were not always consistent and sometimes asked too much of us in the given time frame.
The quality of the course varies significantly by nature and ability of the client organization.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Met with Professor every 2 weeks for 15 mins. This was helpful to keep in touch.
Yes, both Kit Kennedy and TA Haley were available and helpful
Both were very available and eager to be consulted for any advice.
Excellent- Engaging with the professor and TA was a built-in component of the Clinic.
Kit and Hayley were very available and supportive through the semester.

Instructor's feedback was generally cursory, not particularly insightful or helpful. Didn't ask the TA for any substantive feedback but she was on top of everything in regards to the administration of the course, and the administration of the course is very complex. Seems like the clinic would fall apart without her.

I found both the professor and the TA extremely helpful. I probably contacted Haley more often, and she was very responsive. Kit was very knowledgeable, and I greatly appreciated her perspective as well.

The instructor and TA were very responsive to questions. The TA did a fantastic job with organizing client calls and working with so many different schedules. The professor provided helpful feedback on work products
Both Kit and Hayley were fantastic.
Both were responsive and flexible.

Both Kit and Hayley were very helpful outside of class in assisting each of us with our clinic projects. They were both very accessible by email as well. It was nice to know that we would receive a response within a few hours rather than having to wait a day or two.
Although we did not require Hayley's assistance for our project specifically, she did do an excellent job of managing a large and diverse set of groups/projects.
Both were very helpfull
The TA was very helpful in answering questions about logistics and was very organized. The instructor was good at directing us to other helpful people if she could not help us directly.
They are both very helpful
Always available and always helpful.
Very good, easily accessible

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: A good class framework to add client experience to your CV.
I think it's good practice working with a client on a real project. This experience is useful for future career work.
This course is a must for any students wishing to go into a field at the intersection of environmental management and law.
Insofar as I hope to work for an NGO in the conservation field, this was excellent preparation for what that will actually be like.
Completely fits and is a very valuable part of my education.
This course provided me with insights into the policy aspects of the issues I want to work on in my career. As such, it will be VERY useful to me going forward.

The interdisciplinary nature of the clinic is something that doesn't always come through in all of the FES courses, but in the way the projects are designed there is more of an ability to interact with a group of economists, scientist, and lawyers in each of their specialities.
This class provided an excellent opportunity to conduct research and analysis in an area of interest not specifically addressed within the FES course offerings.
The energy project available in this class fits in very well with my energy concentration.
Allowed for a specialization into area of interest.
Helps build practical and real world experiences while developing academic rigor

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To do work for an outside client.

Wanted to work with a client and demands of the course outside of the client project seemed minimal. I also expected to gain new insights on the topics outlined in the syllabus: negotiation, advocacy writing, basics of environmental law.
There was a client who I wanted to work with.

Again, I thought it would be strong preparation for the real world, and I also wanted to feel like I was accomplishing more at FES than just producing a litany of opaque academic papers. Also, the specific project that I wanted to work on was right up my alley, and I wanted to get involved with that particular organization.
Opportunity to work with a client and feel like I was making a contribution.
Because it gives me real life experience in something completely relevant to my career goals
To continue working with my client
Opportunity to explore a policy issue I care about.
I was really interested in two of the clinic projects offered this semester and to gain practical experience rather than working on a purely academic exercise.
See response to question 16.
I wanted to work for one particular client.
To have the opportunity to work with my client.
I wanted to apply my skills to a real project.
allowed for specialization.
Wanted to have a clinical experience

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes
Not entirely. The class sessions themselves were very basic and did not teach anything I didn't already know. I did enjoy the experience working with a client.
Yes.
No. I enjoyed my project but the course itself fell short expectations.
Well, I had a hard time with the very heavy 12-hr-per-week workload, but I guess that was my own fault.Otherwise, it was great.
yes!
Yes
Yes.
Yes.
Yes it did.
For the most part.
yes.
Yes,

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes
Yes.

I think there is so much variation with the client and the team that you work with, that sometimes it works well, and sometimes it doesn't. I would have liked to learn more about the environmental side of the project as opposed to working just on the policy/administrative questions, but that is what the client asked for.
Yes, I think so.
Yes
Yes
Yes.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes
yes.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: the entire course is based around team projects so it's sort of a moot question.
As always, some people work harder than others.

One member of my group did not seem to be doing any work on the project and admitted that. But when we all posted our work hours, I was surprised that the member had logged so many hours. I wondered if she/he was exaggerating their hours worked or just being VERY inefficient.

All of the clinic projects are very group oriented. This was an interesting and valuable experience as you get to experience how students in other fields (law, business, forestry) approach different problems. It also encourages creativity and innovation within the project.
Disparate skills sets. This is an advantage and disadvantage, but it is certainly important to practice working in a diverse group.

I really enjoyed my co-workers. They were all more knowledgeable than me, so I learned a lot from interacting with them. They were also just nice, interesting people who were pleasant to be around. And it was nice to have someone to share the workload, too. On the downside, they had all been working on this project for a while, and it was hard for me to just pick up in midstream. It took a couple months for me to really find my niche within the group.
Group members took on various roles. This semester I took the clinicfor 1 credit, so my experience this semester was very different from last, but still rewarding.

Advantages: exchange of ideas, ability to divide work, more individuals to keep the group on track time-wise, more perspectives and expertise brought to bear on the issue.Disadvantages: some things take more time to resolve, scheduling.

Working on an interdisciplinary team is hard work. We were very good about having weekly meetings and keeping everyone up to date on our research progress. Having students on different schedules was sometimes a disadvantage to meeting deadlines in the clinic but this is unavoidable and by careful scheduling it can be overcome entirely.

Having group members with diverse talents was extremely helpful in tackling research and analysis questions, but having many members on the team with sometimes conflicting schedules did occasionally slow progress of the team overall.
It was great for me to measure myself against my teammates. I learned a lot from them.
Working in a group was required to divide up the work and collaborate on the methodology for calculations.
We could have better division on our work.
Managing everyone's schedules.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Choose a project that really excites you, and understand that the client project is a substantial time commitment. Plan to log 12 hrs/wk on the project. Several people lagged behind in working on their project each week and ended up cramming their work into the last couple weeks classes/exams.

I would advise clarifying the expectations of your client. Write follow up emails after conference calls and rest assured that even if the beginning of the semester seems to go at a slow pace-- it will pick up in the end!
You should really like your project inorder to stay motivated through the semester.
Pick your project carefully and don't take it if you don't get the project you want.

Definitely be proactive. Some clients probably tell you exactly what they need and want from you, but my client left it pretty open-ended. I wish that I worked harder to find a role of my own, rather than just picking up loose ends from my teammates.
Keep up with your hours!
Take as many Clinics as you can, it's so worth it.
Make room for it. It will take much more time than you anticipate to produce a quality product.

Make sure to define group tasks as clearly as possible and even sharing a google document where people have to check off tasks would be helpful. A few times we would assign tasks and then weren't sure if certain things got done. In the clinic, you are pretty much putting most of your colleagues on the honor system to get things done and the checking up to make sure everyone is doing what they said they were doing part can be difficult at times. I think an internal checklist shared with the group members could create more accountability with group members.

If there is a project offered that you are interested in (or one you can bring into the clinic) then definitely pursue the opportunity to work on it and build professional relationships outside of the FES community.
You need to commit a lot of time.
Keep up with the given number of hours per week and don't get behind, even if it means pushing your client a bit to give direction.
Take it.
Do the clinic work early in the semester so that there is time to further develop project with client as new issues come up.
Dont miss taking this course once if not twice during your 2 years !
